koohiiStory1: You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.
koohiiStory2: Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to expose her “beaver” pelt, so you have to encourage her with your fingers to expose it.
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Press your fingers in someone's skin to expose what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Close your eyes. Picture someone's arm. Now touch their skin with your fingers and peel it back to expose the muscles and bones underneath.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine the heat steaming out, like it's coming out of a teapot, not out of somebody's arm skin.

humanum_full_description_en:
From the sound of " hand " and " skin ", it means division. "Shuowen": "While holding it from the side, you can put it on. From the hand, the skin sounds." "Zuo Zhuan‧ The Five Years of Zhaogong": "Killing is suitable for Lishu, and then piercing the town."

" Phi " can mean splitting. "Historical Records-The Five Emperors Benji": "Only Yu's contribution is great, he will cover the nine mountains, pass through the nine mountains, determine the Jiuhe, and set the Jiuzhou.

" Phi " also means toggling and opening. Jin Zuosi "Miscellaneous Poems": "Pixuan is facing the front courtyard, and the morning geese are flying."

" Phi " also means to break or cut. "Warring States Policy‧Qin Cesan": "Those who drape the branches of the woods are broken, and those who drape the branches break their hearts."

" Phi " also means to open and read. Han Bangu "East Capital Fu": "Hold Qian's Talisman, interpret Kunzhen, put on the emperor's picture, and Jidiwen."

" Phi " also means to disperse. "The Book of the Later Han Dynasty·Zhong Shao Zhuan": "Shao anger, called the edict and screamed, and the sergeants were all dressed, and then the previous accusation was outstanding."

" Phi " also refers to disclosure and statement. Southern Song Dynasty Xie Lingyun "Chou Congdi Huilian": "The end is worth your brother, open face and heart."

" Placing " also means covering or putting clothes on the shoulders. The King of Han praised "Nine Huai·Zhao Shi": "I wear British clothes with tucked folds, and Chinese clothes are fragrant."
humanum_short_description_en: From the sound of " hand " and " skin ", it means division.
humanum_full_description:
從「手」，「皮」聲，表示分割。《說文》：「从旁持曰披。从手，皮聲。」 《左傳‧昭公五年》：「殺適立庶，又披其邑。」

　　「披」可表示劈開。《史記‧五帝本紀》：「唯禹之功為大，披九山，通九澤，決九河，定九州。」

　　「披」也表示撥動、打開。晉左思〈雜詩〉：「披軒臨前庭，嗷嗷晨鴈翔。」

　　「披」亦表示折斷、割斷。《戰國策‧秦策三》：「木實繁者披其枝，披其枝者傷其心。」吳師道補正：「披，折也。」

　　「披」還表示翻開、翻閱。漢班固〈東都賦〉：「握乾符，闡坤珍，披皇圖，稽帝文。」

　　「披」也指散去。《後漢書‧种劭傳》：「劭怒，稱詔大呼叱之，軍士皆披，遂前質責卓。」

　　「披」還指披露、陳述。南朝宋謝靈運〈酬從弟惠連〉：「末路值令弟，開顏披心胸。」

　　「披」亦指覆蓋或搭衣於肩。漢王褒《九懷‧昭世》：「襲英衣兮緹褶，披華裳兮芳芬。」
